actions

The basic building blocks of an activity diagram (or flowchart) are actions, each a statement or sequence of statements in the code. Each action conceptually accomplishes a discrete task. A sequence of actions builds up an activity. The actions, along with the level of detail to which they correspond (zoom level), are specified in the source code by the programmer.

Annotations describing actions are the key added elements that allow Flowgen to generate a rich description. An annotation specifies what succeeding lines of code (up to the next annotation or an annotated flow-control structure) are doing. The added ‘$’ distinguishes an annotation from a regular C++ comment, allowing the programmer to choose explicitly what appears in the activity diagrams.

annotation

      ...
      //$ do something
      //$ and other thing as well
      code

representation in the diagram

*width of the text before line return: a configurable option of the system [not implemented].
See also Action_modifiers.

examples


int class::activity_method(){

int a; 

//$ do something
//$ and other thing as well
//*************************
// we print using std::cout
std::cout << "do 1"<< endl;
std::cout << "do 2"<< endl;

return 0;
}
      

      
int class::activity_method(){

int a; 

//$ do something
//$ and other thing as well

// we print using std::cout
std::cout << "do 1"<< endl;
std::cout << "do 2"<< endl;

return 0;
}
      
      
int class::activity_method(){

int a; 

//$ do something
// we print using std::cout
std::cout << "do 1"<< endl;

//$ do other thing
std::cout << "do 2"<< endl;

return 0;
}
